qas.question: What was a desirable feature of Georgian town planning?
What decorative vocabulary did Georgian designs draw from?
What was considered a deep flaw of Georgian architecture?
What type of architecture was known for its asymmetry and balance?
What was an undesirable feature of Georgian town planning?
Why were Georgian additions where earlier structures remained visible so approved of?
What type of designs laid in the classical orders after the Gothic revival?
What kind of ratios were used in Gothic revival architecture?

context: <b4_0>Georgian<b4_0/> architecture is characterized by <a0_0>its proportion and balance<a0_0/>; simple <b8_0>mathematical ratios<b8_0/> were used to determine the height of a window in relation to its width or the shape of a room as a double cube. Regularity, as with ashlar (uniformly cut) stonework, was strongly approved, imbuing symmetry and adherence to classical rules: the <a3_0><b6_0>lack of symmetry<b6_0/><a3_0/>, where Georgian additions were added to earlier structures remaining visible, was deeply felt as a flaw, at least before Nash began to introduce it in a variety of styles. <a1_0><b5_0>Regularity of housefronts<b5_0/><a1_0/> along a street was a desirable feature of Georgian town planning. Until the start of the Gothic Revival in the early 19th century, <b7_0>Georgian designs<b7_0/> usually lay within the Classical orders of architecture and employed a decorative vocabulary derived from <a2_0>ancient Rome or Greece<a2_0/>.
